title: LG G2 4.2.2
comment: Cannot complite installation because console asks anything and does not accept any pressed key, even enter ((  another thing is that boostrap script does not use provided custom botbrew install path. Otherwise idea is great. Will check later.

title: It broke my tablet (JB4.1), had to reflash to fix it.
comment: Using on a Pro Tab 2 XXL Jelly Bean 4.1 Stock ROM (Same as Go Clever A103) I couldn't input a requested option during apt-get setup because the stock keyboard would not write on the terminal window opened during installation. I had to close the app and when I tried to reinstall the whole system crashed and the tablet would not reboot (it got stuck on boot logo every time I tried). I had to reflash the ROM. Be warned: experimental support means experimental.

title: Crippled device, barely able to uninstall
comment: Okay, I understand experimental. But what did this thing do, start trying to play with mounts?!! After installing this thing, it showed nothing available, so I assumed it was broken and forgot. Later, my wallpaper was gone (custom wallpaper slideshow app), "unfortunately,..." errors left and right, and trying to uninstall BotBrew just crashed Package Installer.  Also needs a better description... I was linked directly to this experimental build and didn't know "experimental" meant "look below for stable"!

title: not good
comment: cant install pkg.zip

title: Interesting
comment: This originally wouldn't install on my rooted S4 i9505. After installing Cyanogenmod it finally "worked" but unfortunately, as I was in the middle of the process of installing debian I got stuck on a Y/N command since the shell wouldn't detect my keyboard. I eventually had to force quit and reboot my phone but that's where it began getting even more buggy. After uninstalling, deleting the bootstrap directory and reinstalling I decided to try again. Long story short, everything (meaning literally everything) crashed and my phone got bricked in the process.  It's an exciting project but obviously still extremely buggy. I'll try reinstalling this later today as soon as I unbrick my S4 and get everything working again. I look forward seeing further developments.

title: Really?
comment: I'll knock this up to 5-stars if this is just a bug, rather than a major design flaw but... It seems like the console doesn't accept keyboard input. I selected the minimal Debian option, and apt is asking which version of a file I want, but I can't enter a response -- no characters appear in the terminal?

comment: Very promising, but won't behave on my phone just yet...

title: Thank you!
comment: That's what we need to really use our phones, and call them smartphones!

title: Better stability with Anise
comment: (I know - beware the bleeding edge)  Having apt is a great resource,  but it's overshadowed by some serious issues (for my device, anyway) - my entire filesystem has been symlinked through Botbrew, which seems to be causing my sdcard to mount/unmount at random. Tried to uninstall, still symlinked, and still able to run botbrew programs. I'd like to completely remove it and return to Anise, but short of restoring to a nandroid backup, I don't even know where to start. Developer hasn't answered email
